title: Old Christmas - History, traditions and celebrations of Jan. 6 holiday

The 12 days of Christmas ended on Jan. 6 and some cultures, such as Armenians and Irish, continued to celebrate on this date.
In Appalachia and among the Amish and Mennonites, Old Christmas is celebrated with traditions like family gatherings, holiday foods, and superstitions about animals speaking at midnight.

Deena Kilmon's first year as executive director of the Waterfowl Festival saw the event attract 25,000-30,000 attendees and set multiple records for attendance and revenue. The event has an economic impact of over $3 million annually and benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers, and nonprofits.

title: Talbot County considering new cannabis legislation
content: Talbot County is reviewing regulations on cannabis operations, with drafted legislation proposing a 500-foot setback from residential properties. Two state license holders, Dave Ferraris and Lori Yates, expressed concerns over the restrictions during a public hearing on July 8. The county's planning and zoning director noted that a 200-foot setback is possible if affected property owners agree. The legislation would require processors and growers to operate on at least 20-acre lots and procure professional testimony on cannabis odor.

title: New exhibition at AAM features artist Darlene R. Taylor
content: A new art exhibition titled "HEIRLOOMS" by artist Darlene R. Taylor has debuted at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, Maryland, running through July 14. The exhibition features mixed-media collages using vintage linens and textiles collected from family albums and historical archives. Taylor's work explores the presence of Black women in Maryland's Talbot County communities and her own ancestry. The exhibition draws inspiration from artifacts unearthed during excavations at the Hill Community site, including personal items such as buttons, jewelry, and hair combs.

title: Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County
content: Natural Resources Police used thermal imaging to rescue a lost juvenile kayaker in Broad Creek, Talbot County, on July 4, 2025. The kayaker was found within five minutes of being located by a Natural Resource Police aviation unit led by Sgt. John Buchanan and tactical flight officer Christian Helwig. The rescue occurred around three miles from the kayaker's home, near Grace Creek.

title: Callahan and Lesher reelected as Talbot County Council leadership
content: Talbot County Council members reelected Chuck Callahan as president and Pete Lesher as vice president in Tuesday's election. Callahan has been a council member since December 1, 2014, while Lesher joined the council on December 3, 2018. The reelected leadership retained its positions from the prior year.

title: Where has grace gone in winning?
content: Dan McKew questions where grace has gone in winning, citing a lack of decorum and respectful behavior in politics, particularly in debating tactics that would be scolded in children. He advocates for shaking hands and respecting opponents, even those he disagreed with, as a measure of character. McKew fears many today's loudest voices would fail to pass this test.

title: Celebrating the Fourth
content: Three hundred-plus people gathered in St. Michaels on July 4, 2025, for the annual Children's Parade, led by Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald and carrying a flag from Scout Troop 741. The parade featured children marching through downtown with their families, who had traveled to the area from places like Denver, Colorado. A traditional Fourth of July program followed the parade at the St. Michaels Historical Museum, including patriotic songs.

title: Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal
content: The Talbot Board of Education reviewed its proposed budget for fiscal year 2026, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars, an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025. The areas with highest increases are fixed charges ($2.23 million), instructional salaries ($1.7 million), and other instructional costs ($1.47 million). The proposed budget includes 33 additional positions, including English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants, and coaches, and an athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School. The district's top priorities were academic equity in math, engaging environment, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.

title: Konner loved Paint Tilghman — we think you will too
content: Star Democrat reporter Konner Metz attended Plein Air Easton's Paint Tilghman event on Tilghman Island in July 2025, where artists competed to capture the island's scenic beauty, including those from England.

title: ESCR offering free introductory lessons
content: ESCR is an adult rowing team based at Evergreen in Easton, MD. They are offering free introductory lessons and two Learn-to-Row clinics from April 28-May 1 and May 12-15. The cost of a full clinic session is $400 for 10 hours. ESCR is open to anyone over 18 interested in learning rowing, with no experience or swimming requirements being an obstacle for assistance.

title: Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts
content: Talbot County Democrats celebrated election night with a party at the BAAM Center, featuring over 200 individual volunteers who helped with the campaign. The celebration came after record-breaking canvassing efforts in Talbot County and hopes for a "blue" state in Maryland. Kamala Harris won the U.S. Senate seat in Maryland, while Donald Trump flipped several swing states in his favor to win the presidential election. Democratic Party leaders acknowledged division among voters but emphasized universal values like clean water, education, and safety.

title: Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking
content:

A panel highlighted signs of trafficking, such as bruises, new tattoos, and suspicious online activity, and emphasized the need for community awareness and vigilance. title: Monster munchies: Duff Goldman and Rosanna Pansino host creepy cookie contest
content: Celebrity pastry chef Duff Goldman and social media sensation Rosanna Pansino host "Halloween Cookie Challenge", a Food Network competition where contestants compete to make creepiest, spookiest, and tastiest Halloween cookies. The show airs Mondays through October 2023 on the Food Network. Contestants face challenges such as creating edible stained glass, giant Halloween fun houses, and playable spirit boards. The winner takes home a $10,000 trick-or-treat bag each episode, with a grand prize of $40,000 at the end of the season.

title: Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown
content: County Republicans continued to push Talbot County Board of Elections on election judge breakdown during the board's monthly meeting. The current breakdown is 62 Democratic judges, 50 Republican judges, and 11 unaffiliated judges, with local officials citing state law that requires equal numbers of judges from each party. State agencies have emphasized election security and compliance with law, while Attorney General Anthony Brown said it's not possible to achieve exact party balance due to factors outside the local board's control. The Board of Elections accepts interest forms for election judges continuously and provides training, but some Republicans claim they were not informed of vacancies for this year's general election.

title: 13th annual Watermen’s Appreciation Day draws a crowd
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

The 13th annual Watermen's Appreciation Day was held at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on August 12, 2024, drawing hundreds of people to celebrate local watermen and fundraiser for the Talbot Watermen's Association. The event, started in 2010 by association president Jeff Harrison, has grown in popularity over the years with a strong showing from the local community. The museum benefits from admission intake, while also partnering with watermen on fundraising efforts. The event featured boat docking contests, steamed crabs, live music, and family activities, with volunteers including Ashley and James Harrison, who started volunteering at age 10 and continued with their children.

title: WHCP running membership drive through Nov. 11
content: WHCP running membership drive through Nov. 11 with a matching gift of $10,000 from an anonymous local donor. The station offers diverse musical styles and Mid-Shore news updates, with a goal to support its public radio offerings. WHCP is one of 17 NPR member stations offering the NPR+ podcast bundle as a thank-you gift for annual memberships. Individual annual memberships start at $35, with sustaining monthly membership options available for less than $7/month.

title: YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 sentences:

The YMCA in Easton, Maryland was closed on Saturday after two fires broke out, one involving a second-floor closet and the other an HVAC unit on the roof. The fires were extinguished with minimal damage to the building, but the racquetball courts had to be closed due to water damage. The cause of the first fire is still under investigation while the second was attributed to a mechanical failure with the HVAC unit. Regular operations resumed Sunday morning with all facilities open except the racquetball courts, which are expected to reopen soon.

title: 'How Lucky Is This Community' - Connect Talbot Project Celebrated For Its Success
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Easton Utilities' Connect Talbot project was celebrated on September 21, 2023, by over 60 representatives from the U.S. Department of Agriculture for its continued progress in extending broadband to unserved portions of Talbot County, MD. The USDA awarded Easton Utilities $13.1 million in grant funding in July 2020, which has since been supplemented with additional funding sources totaling over $30 million. As of early September, the project had completed over 50% of its mileage construction and provided access to over 1,750 locations, with 920 subscribers enjoying internet service. The project is on track for completion by December 31, 2026, with Easton Utilities' president Hugh Grunden crediting partnerships with the USDA, state and local governments, and others as key to its success.

title: Local health care 'excellent'
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

Cindy Genther experienced a stroke on August 17, 2024, and received excellent care at local health facilities. She was transported to Chester River Hospital by ambulance, where Dr. Lukas evaluated her condition and recommended she remain for further evaluation. After being transferred to an acute-care facility in Easton, she received exceptional care from doctors, nurses, and staff, including Dr. Devkota and Dr. Valentin. Genther has praised the local healthcare system, citing "exceptional" service, highly skilled professionals, and a caring attitude.

title: St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board holds first meeting
content: The St. Michaels Tourism Advisory Board held its first meeting at the Boy Scout Cabin in St. Michaels on January 24, 2025. The board discussed budgets, marketing and branding strategies, including combining websites and understanding tourist demographics. Members included Timothy Law, representing retail businesses, and Brian Ball, managing director of the Wildset Hotel. The board aims to assist the town in promoting tourism and encouraging businesses to locate or remain in St. Michaels.

title: Waterfowl Festival looks forward
content: Deena Kilmon is the new executive director of the Waterfowl Festival, a year-round effort with events and conservation efforts. The festival welcomes 20,000 visitors in November at the Armory in Easton, Maryland, featuring art sales, demonstrations, and educational events. Kilmon plans to revitalize the Armory's space, including restoring historically accurate windows and fixing the roof, aiming to turn it into a community center with ongoing events. She also aims to connect with younger members of the community through new initiatives.

title: For All Seasons partners for suicide intervention
content: For All Seasons is partnering with Santé Eastern Shore to offer a LivingWorks ASIST training on April 7-8 at Anchor Church in Easton. The two-day workshop will teach caregivers how to recognize suicidal thoughts and provide support. Participants will receive 12 Category I CEUs and registration is $350 due by March 31.

title: Holiday Pottery Sale at AAM
content: The Academy Art Museum in Easton, MD will host its Holiday Pottery Sale on December 9 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The event features works by artists and students taking pottery classes at the museum, with proceeds benefiting the clay program. AAM is located at 106 South Street in Easton.

title: Bridge - Deception by deduction
content: John Ruskin discussed deception in lying in bridge. In a recent deal, East deliberately dropped his queen of hearts to deceive South's declarer. The ruse was successful due to prior communication through the auction, where South had shown four hearts. This allowed East to afford playing his heart queen safely, as he knew South would have played a heart to dummy's king if they started with A-Jx-x.

title: Commissioners of Oxford table voting resolution
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article in 4 sentences:

Oxford Commission President Norm Bell recommended voting on a resolution to clarify voting registration requirements March 13, 2025, but the commission tabled it in a two-to-one vote. Commissioner Katrina Greer expressed concerns that rushing into the vote could delay its effectiveness for the town's upcoming election in June. The commission held a work session Feb. 25 and again March 5 to discuss the issue, with some residents sharing thoughts on voting eligibility. Commissioner Tom Costigan voted against tabling the resolution, but suggested writing rules for the Oxford Election Board instead.

title: Rabbi Hyman delivers multicultural understanding
content:
Rabbi Peter Hyman DD is retiring from Temple B'nai Israel after 18 years as its first full-time rabbi in October 2024.
He has promoted multicultural understanding and respect for different religious beliefs, owning a Persian rug with 99 names of God in Arabic that he views as a metaphorical bridge between faiths.
Rabbi Hyman has received numerous awards for his interfaith work, including the NAACP Dorothy Webb Black Community Service Legacy Award and the Governor William Donald Schaefer Helping People Award.
He is an author, teacher, and Scouting leader who earned his Eagle Scout award in 1984 and served as a national chair for the Messengers of Peace Program, BSA.
Rabbi Hyman will continue to serve on the Eastern Shore despite his retirement.

title: Talbot council mulling $1.1 million request from school district
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Talbot County Public Schools is seeking $1.1 million from the Talbot County Council for fiscal year 2026 to fill nine new positions and provide teacher salary increases.
The request is "scaled-back" from the district's earlier ask of $5.7 million, with leaders saying it's a necessary step to address financial pressures.
Council members are deliberating on whether to grant the full funding, with some supporting the reduced amount and others indicating they need more time to consider options.
A final decision is expected at the council's May 27 meeting, which will include an education supplement to the property tax rate, potentially resulting in a 0.0106 per $100 of assessed value increase.

title: Average gas prices continue falling in Maryland
content: Average gasoline prices in Maryland fell 3.7 cents per gallon to $2.91 per gallon on Monday, according to GasBuddy's survey of 2,167 stations. The national average price of diesel declined 1.8 cents to $3.472 per gallon. Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy, predicted the falling prices may be coming to an end due to rising oil prices above $70.

title: Kids show their skills at the Talbot County Fair

title: Talbot's advanced life support pioneers reflect on program's 40-year mark
content: Five Easton firefighters began a new advanced life support program on August 13, 1985, with just one vehicle from the fire department. The "first five" pioneers included Wayne Dyott, Kevin Knussman, Marc Stockley, Ray Taylor, and the late Gary Jones. Over 40 years later, Talbot County's paramedic services have expanded to six ALS units and over 50 staff members, saving around 6,800 calls last year.

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
content: J.R. Dobson was elected Easton fire chief in December 2024 and officially took on the role this month. He has experience as patrol and operations commander at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and plans to recruit and retain more volunteers for the department. Dobson aims to implement standard operating procedures, purchase a utility vehicle for Rails to Trails and woods fires, and buy a new engine.

title: Tunis Mills bridge replacement project moves forward
content: The Talbot County Council agreed to move forward with replacing the Leeds Creeks Bridge in Tunis Mills with a wooden deck and timber wearing surface, as proposed by County Engineer Ray Clarke, after months of resident input. The project costs around $6.5 million, with $1.5 million coming from the county and the rest federally funded. Advocates for a 100% wooden replacement, including Susan McDermott and John Tabori, expressed concerns but welcomed the changes to the proposal. The council unanimously approved the project as presented, with Vice President Pete Lesher thanking Clarke's team for their efforts and expressing hope that federal funding comes through despite potential suspensions.

title: Maryland House and Garden tour lets visitors explore Talbot County properties
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article:

Canterbury Manor in Easton, MD was one of several historic properties visited during the Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage tour, which benefits preservation and restoration efforts in historically significant properties across the state. Proceeds from the tour go toward preserving Talbot County properties, including the restoration of Scotts United Methodist Church and St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Trappe. title: Seaplane crashes into Harris Creek, pilot uninjured, state police say
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 sentences:

State troopers and Maryland Natural Resources Police responded to the scene, with assistance from Towboat U.S. The incident occurred around noon.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: The Lenten season
content:

Ash Wednesday marks the beginning of the Lenten season, a day associated with mortality and repentance that dates back to ancient Jewish tradition. title: 'A complicated matter with a lengthy history:' Lakeside resolutions remain pending
content:
Lakeside at Trappe development has been pending approval since its plan for wastewater treatment was approved in recent years. Despite construction underway and some homes already built, efforts to implement county oversight remain unresolved. Three pieces of legislation remain pending approval from the Talbot County Council, including Resolution 281, which aims to upgrade water and sewer services for the development.

The planning commission initially found Resolution 281 consistent with the comprehensive plan in 2020, but later rescinded its approval in 2021 due to concerns with nutrient discharge to the Chesapeake Bay. The county council approved the legislation despite these concerns, and it was later challenged by environmental groups before being revised to reduce wastewater flow.

In 2023, a revised permit allowing for a significantly smaller wastewater treatment plant was issued, but the Maryland Department of the Environment still seeks clarification on some specifics of the development. Two new resolutions, 338 and 348, aim to address these issues, including requirements for certification from the planning commission and updates to water and sewer service maps.

The Talbot County Council is set to hold public hearings on all three pieces of legislation in February, giving residents an opportunity to weigh in on the unresolved measures.

title: Trappe election canceled; incumbents will retain seats until 2029
content: The Trappe Town Council election was canceled due to a lack of opposition, with incumbents Brian Schmidt, Walter Chase Sr., and Jeremy Newnam being unopposed in their bids for reelection. Newnam won a special election last year. Their new terms will end in May 2029.

title: Decline of civil dialog in society is a threat
content:

The 2024 presidential election campaign and its aftermath are generating widely different reactions in deeply divided America. The attempted assassination at a Pennsylvania rally has been met with various conspiracy theories on both sides of the political divide. A decline in civil dialogue, characterized by vicious disagreements and demonization of opponents, is seen as the greatest existential threat to democracy in America. title: Inflation: Higher prices for car insurance, beer, housing, fabric, baby formula
content:
Inflation rose 3.2% in February compared to a year ago, with higher prices for housing, car insurance, dining, and items such as beer and baby formula.
U.S. prices are up 20% from before the COVID pandemic and its shutdowns, and 18.6% since January 2021 when President Joe Biden took office.
Rents increased by 5.7% in February, while car insurance rates rose 20.6%, and prices for baby formula jumped 8.8%.
Beer prices are up 4.1%, while housing costs contributed to the overall 3.2% CPI inflation rate, with affordable housing remaining a concern.
U.S. prices were higher during Trump's term in office (2017-2021), rising 7.7%.

title: History is filled with many 'what if' questions
content: Historian Fred Kaplan argues that if President John Kennedy had not been assassinated in November 1963, the outcome and duration of the Vietnam War would have been different. Kennedy's leadership during the Cuban Missile Crisis, particularly his decision to accept a Soviet proposal to remove nuclear missiles from Cuba in exchange for removing American missiles from Turkey, suggests he may have avoided escalation in Vietnam. If Kennedy had lived, America might have avoided a futile and divisive war resulting in over 58,000 deaths and widespread PTSD among veterans.

title: Art exhibit in Easton uses small items to explore larger themes such as war, homelessness
content: Anita Groener's art exhibit "To the Edge of Your World" at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, MD, uses small-scale items to explore themes such as war and homelessness. The exhibit, created by Dutch-Irish artist Anita Groener, features grid-like drawings and bird-chirping sounds, including two sculpture works titled Cradle and Shrapnel made from twigs collected over 10 years. title: Ruth Emma Santucci (Dietrich)
content: Ruth Emma Dietrich Santucci, born August 21, 1928, in Fleetwood, Pennsylvania, died June 24, 2023, at age 94, after years of declining health. She was a devoted teacher, graduating from Mansfield State Teacher's College and later completing a graduate degree at George Washington University. Ruth married Hubert Chester Santucci on August 22, 1953, in Hershey, Pennsylvania, and continued teaching until the births of her daughters. She was survived by her four daughters, seven grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren, and will be cremated and buried with her husband at the Eastern Shore Veteran's Cemetery.

title: Frederick Douglass' Valentine's Day birthday honored by his family
content: Frederick Douglass never knew his exact birthday due to slavery's lack of record-keeping, but he celebrated on Valentine's Day as it was called "his little Valentine" by his mother. Born in 1818 in Talbot County, Maryland, Douglass fled slavery in 1838 and became a prominent abolitionist orator. His family, the Bailey-Groce Family Foundation, honors his legacy with annual birthday celebrations from February 14-20, featuring performances by relatives such as singer Ayla Dennis, to fundraise for African American Cultural Centers and Historical Societies.

title: Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police
content:

The investigation, conducted by the U.S. Department of Justice, revealed that tests disproportionately impacted Black and female applicants, particularly physical fitness tests for women and written tests for Black candidates. title: Filing auto insurance claims
content:

Car insurance companies may increase premiums or cancel coverage if a claim is filed.
There are situations where filing an auto insurance claim is necessary, including:
- Injuries to yourself or others
- Damage to vehicles or property
- Contacting the insurer after a crash with another driver, especially when fault isn't clear.
Filing a claim in these situations ensures coverage applies and prevents unexpected bills or lawsuits.
In contrast, not filing a claim may protect premiums for drivers who are only involved and have minor damage.

content: Billy Long, the IRS commissioner from Missouri who served for two months, has left his position and is expected to be nominated as U.S. Ambassador to Iceland. He had little tax expertise before being chosen by the president in 2025. The IRS has experienced a decline in morale due to his leadership, with thousands of employees leaving since January. Despite this, over 266 million tax returns were filed with the IRS in fiscal year 2024, collecting $98 billion in enforcement revenue.

title: Legislation seeks to make persimmons the state fruit
content: Sen. Arthur Ellis introduced a bill to make persimmons the state fruit of Maryland on January 3, 2024. Persimmons are native to the state and have been used for food, medicine, and other purposes by indigenous people and during the Civil War. The fruit is now worth around $6 per pound, with Ellis stating he has trees in his yard that grow naturally. If Senate Bill 74 passes, it would become effective October 1.

title: From the courtroom to the Chesapeake, 'The Judge' leaves a lasting legacy
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 sentences:

John North died on September 19, 2025, at age 94. He was a well-respected judge who also served as Talbot County state's attorney and chairman of the Maryland Critical Area Commission. North played a crucial role in protecting the Chesapeake Bay's health and implementing local critical area programs. He was known for his fairness, loyalty, and compassion, leaving behind a legacy that is remembered by family, friends, and the community, including through his work with the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum and the St. Michaels Concours d'Elegance.

title: Trappe Planning Commission approves changes to Lakeside plans
content: The Trappe Planning Commission approved changes to the Lakeside Wastewater Treatment Plant plan on August 28, 2024. The Talbot County Health Department and Maryland Department of the Environment requested two changes: one related to the signature approval block and the other to combine three lots for spray irrigation into a single parcel. The commission unanimously approved the motion to authorize Commission President Edgar to sign the revised plans upon Health Department and MDE approval.

title: Encounter with Jimmy Carter provides memories
content: Linda Evans met Jimmy Carter at a cherry blossom event in Washington D.C.'s Tidal Basin in the mid-1970s as part of her job as a personal assistant to George Romney. She was mistaken for Mitt Romney's sister Lynn and shook President Carter's hand, saying "Thank you for being our president." A Secret Service employee had arranged for her to meet the president, and he took a photo with her. Years later, Evans contacted White House Press Secretary Karl Schumaker who claimed to have three photos of her that he would mail or allow her to pick up at the White House.

title: Easton considers ordinance to crack down on seafood processing odors
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article:

The Easton Town Council is considering an ordinance to regulate seafood processing odors in response to complaints from residents living near Chesapeake Brand Seafood on Maryland Avenue. The proposed ordinance would restrict seafood processing in residential areas and require odor control technology, with existing businesses given six months to comply. Councilmembers have mixed views on the proposal, with some expressing concerns about the impact on smaller businesses and others advocating for stricter regulations to alleviate resident complaints.

title: Bridge - The exception to the rule
content: A bridge player bid three notrump to keep a vulnerable game alive with partner's help. Declarer played low clubs to deny East cashing his top suits. West won one trick but was forced to concede the next with declarer's heart king, ultimately losing the game. This unusual deal highlights how exceptions can occur in bridge despite conventional strategies.

title: Mid-Shore could see highs in upper 90s as heat wave approaches
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Mid-Shore counties in Maryland, including Caroline and Talbot, are expected to see temperatures near triple digits from Sunday through Wednesday. The Dorchester County Health Department advises vulnerable groups such as babies, older adults, and pregnant women to take precautions during heatwaves. Easton Fire Chief J.R. Dobson asks residents for water donations due to the physically intensive work of firefighting; local departments are working together to respond to emergencies. Maryland Secretary of Health Dr. Meena Seshamani reminds parents to never leave children in cars during heatwaves.

title: Knox, Easton top Pocomoke, 2-1
content: Easton High field hockey beat Pocomoke City 2-1 on October 8, 2025, with goals from Addie Knox and Lily Tiebosch. Taylor Bowen made eight saves in the game. The win improves Easton's record to 6-3.

title: James saves U.S. from big upset
content: LeBron James saved the U.S. Olympic team from a stunning loss with an 8-second layup that gave the Americans a 101-100 win over South Sudan in London on July 20, 2024. The U.S. team, led by LeBron James and Anthony Davis, rallied from a 16-point deficit to avoid a possible upset against the African nation. Carlik Jones' runner off the glass missed with about 4 seconds left, allowing the Americans to escape with the win.

title: Limits on how much a drug should cost
content: The US government has released a list of 10 medications, including Enbrel, that will be subject to price negotiations under the Medicare reform bill. The list includes medications taken by millions of people and those costing billions to develop, with Enbrel's cost exceeding $1,700 per pen. President Joe Biden announced the start of new negotiations aimed at giving voice to patients and saving Medicare more than $100 billion over 10 years.

title: Delmarva Pride Center brings new world with Dungeons and Dragons
content: The Delmarva Pride Center hosts an open Dungeons & Dragons game on the fourth Saturday of each month, providing a safe space for LGBTQ+ community members and allies to explore gender identity, sexuality, and imagination. The center's host, Lauren Fierman, acts as dungeon master and ensures player comfort and respect for personal boundaries. Players have found the game helpful in exploring their identities and building LGBTQ+ representation in media. The Delmarva Pride Center offers various monthly events, including Gender Expression Movement and Elder and Intergeneration Social.

title: The Zebra Gallery: a place for 'evolutionary' artists
content: Susa Schauer opened The Zebra Gallery in Easton, MD, which features "evolutionary" art and artists, including those with disabilities, such as her daughter-in-law's grandson, who has Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. Schauer was diagnosed with cancer during the COVID-19 pandemic but used it as an opportunity to create her dream gallery. She aims to support local and international artists with a contemporary spin on traditional art, also giving 10% of proceeds to Ehlers Danlos research. The Zebra Gallery has featured artists Ingrid Matuszewski and Adam Himoff, who praised Schauer's energy and enthusiasm for their work.

title: 'A testament to our shared values' - Easton Mayor's Prayer Breakfast marks 40th anniversary Oct. 26
content: Easton Mayor Megan Cook hosted the 40th annual prayer breakfast, bringing together about 150 local leaders to pray and connect over a buffet breakfast at the Tidewater Inn on October 26. The event marked a milestone in fostering community values. Guest speakers Claudia Reyes and Linda Saathoff Brown shared their testimonies of faith and God's healing presence in their lives. Honored guests included former Mayor Robert Willey and State Sen. Johnny Mautz, who presented official citations for Cook and Willey.

title: Trump steps up push for federal defunding of NPR, PBS
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

U.S. President Donald Trump is pushing for federal funding to be eliminated for National Public Radio (NPR) and Public Broadcasting Service (PBS) stations. Congressional Republicans, including U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, are also backing the effort to defund NPR and PBS. The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB), which helps fund PBS and NPR stations nationwide, received $535 million in the most recent annual federal budget. Defunding CPB would have dire consequences for public broadcasting, particularly for rural areas that rely heavily on public media outlets.

title: McCall, Sabres roll past Dragons again
content: Avery McCall scored 29 points and grabbed 20 rebounds as Sts. Peter and Paul High's girls basketball team beat Salisbury School's Dragons 53-32 on January 31, 2025. Junior Kaylin Palmer added eight points and 14 boards for the Sabres. The win extended their Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference win streak to four games, improving their record to 8-8 overall.

title: Star Democrat delivery delayed
content: Production of the November 23, 2024 Star Democrat was delayed due to mechanical issues. The newspaper is expected to be delivered by noon for carriers and likely not arrive via postal service until Monday. The e-edition is available now and can be accessed online.

title: Celebrating Hispanic art and artists with poster contest
content: The Academy Art Museum in Easton hosted a poster competition celebrating Hispanic cultural heritage with a theme of "Ser Hispano, es Ser Valiente" ("Being Hispanic is Being Brave"). The Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center invited community members to participate, and the top three winners were selected from a variety of ages and ethnicities. The first-place winner was Piper Hambleton and Ellis Williams' collaborative poster featuring a tree with flags from every Latin American and Hispanic country attached to its branches. The competition included works by Albert Gamez, Ahias Murillo, and Majo Arrivillaga, who spoke about the importance of representing the Latino community through art.

title: Interim executive director named for Chesapeake Music
content: Margaret Enloe-North was named Interim Executive Director of Chesapeake Music in September 2023. She brings 30 years of nonprofit experience to the role. Based in Easton, MD, Chesapeake Music has been hosting concerts since its founding over 35 years ago.

title: 25-year-old set to bike from Easton to Canada
content: Hayden Kessinger, 25, will bike from Easton to Canada starting June 14, 2025. He previously biked from Baltimore to San Francisco in 70 days in 2023. The ride is motivated by Chris Guillebeau's book "The Happiness of Pursuit". Kessinger plans to use Warm Showers app to coordinate sleeping arrangements and meet new people for support.

title: Talbot County resident named to Maryland Humanities board
content: Jill Ferris, a resident of Talbot County and vice president of education and interpretation at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, was named to the Maryland Humanities board in November 2023. Ferris previously received awards from Maryland History Day and Colgate University for her teaching work, and holds a master's degree in history museum studies from the Cooperstown Graduate Program.

title: Easton minister detained by ICE
content: Daniel Fuentes Espinal, a Honduran-born minister from Easton, MD, was detained by ICE agents on July 22, 2025, while stopping for material at Lowe's; he has been held at the Baltimore ICE detention center since. Espinal had lived in the US since 2001 and served as minister of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015; his family is trying to obtain citizenship legally but have faced backlogs and expenses. Espinal has no criminal record, with over 600 immigrants arrested in Maryland under President Trump having also had no prior charges.

title: Salt truck crews work to keep ice at bay and local businesses open
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 5 sentences:

Darrell Doupnik's landscaping company Greenshore provides salt and snow plow services to local businesses in Easton, MD, for 40 years. On January 19, 2024, his team worked to clear ice from walkways and parking lots despite icy weather, using over 100 bags of salt. Foreman Jerry Widener has 15 years of experience with winter weather and used this knowledge to manage the workload. The storm brought 3-4 inches of snow to Easton, but Doupnik's team found it manageable. The company provides essential services to commercial clients, including banks, schools, and churches, which often show appreciation for their hard work.

title: Songs about the water - Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum continues Changing Chesapeake series
content: Peter Panyon and his band Big Tribe will present "Songs About the Water" at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum's Van Lennep Auditorium on September 28. The concert features songs inspired by local rivers, including "Can't Work the River," which tells a waterman's struggles with the Patuxent River. Panyon, a biologist professor turned musician, has written hundreds of songs drawing from his experiences teaching biology and exploring themes related to valuing our waterways.

title: Be careful what you vote for
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

Larry Pifer wrote about the potential risks of authoritarian governments, including those led by Donald Trump. Trump claimed he would be a "dictator but only for a short time," raising concerns among Americans. He also failed to fulfill many promises made during his first presidential run, such as building a wall with Mexico paying for it and repealing Obamacare. The article warns voters to be cautious of politicians who don't keep their promises and notes that it's difficult to get rid of dictators once elected.

title: 'Heartbeat of Easton Utilities' legacy lives on
content: Vicki Petro retired as vice president of human resources at Easton Utilities on January 13, 2025, after 31 years of service. She began with the organization in 1993 and has shaped the careers of countless employees, overseeing the hiring of 324 individuals during her tenure. Vicki's impact extends beyond Easton Utilities, influencing professionals across Maryland through her Leadership Maryland classes.

title: Lesher withdraws name from Easton Utilities Commission consideration
content: Pete Lesher withdrew his name from consideration for the Easton Utilities Commission on March 12, 2025, following concerns over dual representation as Talbot County Council Vice President and utilities commissioner. The decision was made after a lengthy discussion by the town council, which raised questions about the legality of serving on both bodies under state law.

title: Meet the Wednesday Morning Artists
content: A group of artists gathers every Wednesday at Peachblossom Place in Easton, MD, showcasing their hand-made jewelry, woodworking, and pottery from 9:30 a.m. to 10 a.m. Artist Bill Pavin received encouragement from the group before speaking in front of elected officials in Washington, D.C., advocating for funding of rare diseases research. The meeting takes place on September 17, 2025, with members also enjoying coffee and interacting with their pets, including Robert Gladney's mastiff, Basil.

title: Juvenile crime, reform are top issues for Talbot County police
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Talbot County police reported a 19% increase in calls for service and a 13% increase in reported crime handled by the sheriff's office, including increases in juvenile crimes, petty thefts, and some violent crimes. Sheriff Joe Gamble identified juvenile crimes in schools as a particular issue, citing Easton High School and Middle School as hotspots. Easton Police Chief Alan Lowrey discussed recent local incidents, including homicides, burglaries, and crime on the Rails to Trails pathways, and plans to increase patrols and citations to address concerns. Other police departments in Talbot County reported few issues, with St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald noting two car thefts and Oxford Police Chief Eric Kellner saying his town is "very safe."

title: 'Vision from the beginning': BAAM leaders excited for new academic center
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 5 concise sentences:

Building African American Minds Inc.'s new academic center will be officially opened on December 14, 2024, with a ribbon-cutting ceremony. The center, located on Jowite Street in Easton, Maryland, will serve as a hub for after-school and summer enrichment programs. Dina Daly, executive director of Building African American Minds, hopes the center will expand her organization's reach beyond under-resourced youth in nearby neighborhoods. The facility will host classrooms, a library, media center, and multipurpose dining room on the first floor, with adult workforce programs and GED classes also being offered. Private donors, community donations, and state and federal funding made the $10 million project possible.

content: Mary Hunt suggests combining quick-service food with home cooking to create "semi-homemade" meals on a tight budget. title: 'Spirit of the Shore' CBMM celebrating Watermen's Appreciation Day
content: Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum (CBMM) is celebrating Watermen's Appreciation Day in St. Michaels on August 11 with a 10am-4pm event. The event honors the men and women who work on the Chesapeake Bay, including harvesting crabs and oysters, and features a boat docking contest, steamed crabs, live music, and kids activities. content:

The new plan aims to boost economic opportunity through collaboration between businesses, leaders, developers, and stakeholders. Chesapeake College is suggested as an outstanding organization to lead regional economic development efforts in the Mid-Shore region.

title: Texas tragedy has shown worst of American society
content: A flash flood tragedy in central Texas resulted in an outpouring of sympathy and support from Americans, but also saw numerous vile messages on social media blaming Trump supporters or policy decisions for the tragedy. Former national co-chair Nina Turner called these responses "shameful," while Pod Save America co-hosts John Favreau and Tommy Vietor condemned similar posts as lacking civility. Sen. Chuck Schumer demanded an investigation into weather service vacancies, but Favreau challenged suggestions that staffing levels were directly responsible. The article emphasizes the need for social media users to prioritize decency and respect in their reactions to tragedies like this one.

title: Irene Gurka
content: Irene Gurka, nee Myshak, died December 16 at Hospice House in Easton, MD. She was born and raised in Jermyn, Pennsylvania, and was a member of St. Michael's Orthodox Church, Jermyn, and St. Thekla Orthodox Church, Easton. Irene celebrated her 100th birthday in September and is survived by family members including two daughters, three grandsons, and four great-grandchildren.

title: Life - Rotarians Holding Food Drive In Honor Of Late Lord Scott
content: The Rotary Club of Easton and community partners are hosting a "Drop for Scotty" food drive through December 31 to honor late Lord Scott Sr., who passed away in January 2020. The food drive is named after Scott, who hosted Operation Christmas Spirit since the 1970s, providing meals and gifts to local children. Donations can be dropped off at designated sites or made financially through dropforscotty.com.

title: Suicide of a superpower
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article:

US President Trump's cost-cutting measures are harming America's military power by reducing government-funded research programs and universities. Key players in developing the atomic bomb were universities such as Princeton, University of Chicago, Columbia, and Berkeley. US reliance on scientific advancements will be crucial in future conflicts, which will feature high-tech systems.

title: Bridge - Try to reduce your assets
content: Mark Twain wrote "Tell the truth or trump - but get the trick." In a Bridge game against East's spades led by the club ace, South made a farsighted play of immediately cashing dummy's heart ace and ruffing a heart in their hand. West had raised to game with two top trump honors, leaving declarer (South) concerned about his trump length. South cashed diamond tricks, eventually winning a trump coup against East.

title: States apart, Waterfowl artists build lasting friendships
content: Jim Green and his wife Kara traveled from Hermosa, South Dakota to Easton, Maryland for the Waterfowl Festival. Carol Heiman-Greene and her husband are friends with the Greens, who have been exhibiting at the festival for a decade. The two couples attend the festival annually, describing it as a "family" of artists who welcome newcomers into their group. Jim Green values the creative exchange and camaraderie among fellow artists, which helps him expand his work.

title: Festivals Coming To Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum - Festivals
content: The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum is hosting two festivals: OysterFest on October 28 and the Eastern Shore Sea Glass & Coastal Arts Festival's Holiday Edition on November 18. OysterFest features oysters, live music, kids' activities, and a raw oyster competition. The festival will also showcase guest speakers related to "The Changing Chesapeake" and feature exhibits from CBMM.

title: Drivers need patience on roadways
content: Drivers in Talbot County and Easton need to exercise patience on roadways due to challenging driving conditions such as narrow streets, double parking, and large vehicles. 70-year-old senior driver Joel S. Strobeck is frustrated with younger drivers' impatience, including honking horns, tailgating, and passing on the right side. Strobeck expects younger drivers will become senior drivers themselves and understand the need for extra time to react safely.

title: New art exhibit critiques America's 'consumption culture'
content: Marty Two Bulls Jr.'s exhibition "Dominion" opens at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, MD on September 15, 2023 and runs through August 2024. The exhibit critiques America's consumption culture using the metaphor of the American Bison. Marty Two Bulls Jr., a South Dakota-based Oglaia Lakota artist, created the immersive installation which features QR codes with historical information about its elements.

title: Crusaders extend mastery over Sabres
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Sam Gerdano's Sts. Peter & Paul Crusaders defeated Sabres 5-2 on February 7, 2025, at the Talbot Community Center to clinch second seed in the MIAA B Conference playoffs. Mason Kaplan netted a hat trick and helped set up two goals for Casey Burkom as Sts. Peter & Paul controlled the neutral zone early. The Crusaders led 4-1 before Buel Jenson scored an unassisted goal with 6:45 left to make it 5-2, their final lead. Gerdano's team is seeking confidence and scoring ways after a brief slump.

title: An age in America comes to an end
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 sentences:

Oroville, California, became a shadow of its former self after gold was discovered there in 1848 and eventually petered out by 1900. In 1911, a Native American named Ishi, the last living member of the Yahi tribe, arrived in Oroville and was taken into custody. Anthropologist Alfred Kroeber took Ishi under his care at UC Berkeley, where he worked as a janitor for five years, adapting to modern life despite his traumatic past. Kroeber's wife, Theodora Kracaw Kroeber, wrote the classic anthropological book "Ishi in Two Worlds" about their time with Ishi, describing his remarkable resilience and dignity in the face of cultural change.

title: Thoughts on smart phone restrictions in schools
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

Social psychologist Jonathan Stephen Haidt suggests that smartphone restrictions in schools are not addressing the root causes of anxiety and depression among American youth, citing his book "The Anxious Generation". The decline of play-based childhood, rise of phone-based childhood, and over-reliance on technology have contributed to this trend. Haidt recommends delaying smartphone use until high school, giving children basic phones instead of smartphones, and limiting social media access. Despite efforts to limit screen time, parents and guardians must take responsibility for making decisions that benefit their children's well-being.

title: Annual Back to School Resource Fair: Preparing students for success
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

For All Seasons hosted an annual Back to School Resource Fair at Idlewild Park on August 22, 2024, partnering with the Talbot County Department of Social Services. The event provided hundreds of pre-stuffed backpacks with school supplies and hundreds of children's books from organizations such as Appleseed Books. Over 1,700 people attended, including families in need who received essential items. For All Seasons CEO Beth Anne Dorman said the event sets students up for success by addressing mental health and providing community support. The event has grown significantly since its origin six years ago and will expand next year due to overcrowding.

title: Talbot Interfaith Shelter's Lip Sync Battle returns
content: Talbot Interfaith Shelter's eighth annual Lip Sync Battle Fundraiser will be held on April 27 at the Waterfowl Building in Easton, MD. The event aims to raise $100,000 and features 19 teams competing for top fundraiser title, including local business owners, school faculty, and community leaders. title: Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum celebrates 60 years
content: The Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum is celebrating its 60th year, opening in 1965 at Navy Point with two buildings and becoming accredited in 1978. Pete Lesher, chief historian, said the museum was created by a community effort to preserve the region's history. The museum now features exhibits such as Sailing to Freedom, which highlights the Underground Railroad on the water, and plans to honor African American business owners William Coulbourne and Frederick Jewett with its education building name change.

content:

Cambridge-South Dorchester won its first game of the season with five hat tricks, including Luke Reinbold's five goals against Wicomico 0-21. title: Clow's winning goal lift Easton
content: Easton High's field hockey team defeated James M. Bennett 4-3 in overtime on September 10, 2025. McKenna Clow scored the game-winning goal set up by Ryann Quicke and assisted by Addie Knox. The Warriors' Taylor Bowen made six saves in the win. Easton improved to a 2-1 record.

content: St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald said the police department will lose an 18-year veteran officer due to better pay. title: Talbot OKs bill to begin accepting cannabis funds
content: The Talbot County Council approved a bill on October 14, 2025, allowing it to accept $730,000 from Maryland's Cannabis Reinvestment and Repair Fund. The county will use the funds for community-based initiatives, such as after-school programs, behavioral health services, and housing prevention. Council member Lynn Mielke abstained from voting.

title: 'Proven leader': Easton will soon welcome Kitzrow as new town manager
content: Easton will welcome Andy Kitzrow as its new town manager starting July 7. Kitzrow was chosen by Mayor Megan Cook after conducting full-day interviews with four finalists and is expected to oversee town operations, lead department heads, and be a point of contact with the mayor and Town Council members. Kitzrow, current Salisbury city administrator, has experience working under three different mayors in Salisbury, including Jake Day and Randy Taylor, who will benefit from his connections as he takes on Easton's housing challenges.

title: Letters To The Editor
content: Letters To The Editor from Sept. 29, 2023. A response to David Reel's OpEd calls it "characteristic of the post-2016 American Enterprise sandwich" and criticizes its lack of transparency regarding the author's affiliation with the American Enterprise Institute. title: Plea hearing is scheduled for Rider case
content: Fred "Trey" Rider III is scheduled for a plea hearing on August 19 and a sentencing hearing on October 19, related to setting his house on fire in November 2022. Talbot County Assistant State's Attorney Jennifer Wilson said Rider plans to plead guilty to first-degree arson and five counts of reckless endangerment. Rider's divorce proceedings with Kari Rider are parallel to this case, and it may affect sentencing. The state may seek restitution, but this has not been determined.

title: Easton planners: amid affordable housing shortage, inclusionary zoning may be useful
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article:

Easton planners consider inclusionary zoning to address affordable housing shortage in Easton and Talbot County, with 42% of workers commuting from adjacent counties due to unaffordable housing prices. The proposed ordinance would require residential developers to allocate 15% of units as affordable, with prices capped at area median income levels. Town leaders, including Mayor Megan Cook, believe the ordinance is a critical step in addressing the shortage and promoting mixed-income projects to reduce housing inequities.

title: Police arrest man on charges in overdose
content: A Henderson man, Justin A. Bodman, was arrested on September 28, 2023, for manslaughter and narcotic distribution in connection to an overdose death in Easton that occurred on September 5, 2022. Elina Lazarieva, 23, of Easton, had previously been arrested on August 2, 2023, on similar charges in Baltimore. The duo allegedly sold heroin to Cristian Gonzales, who overdosed and died. Bodman was turned over to the Talbot County Detention Center, while Lazarieva was released on bond on September 12, with her case scheduled for a jury trial in January.

title: Museum seeks information on mystery device
content:
Here is a concise summary of the article:

Volunteers at Trappe's Rural Life Museum are seeking information on an antique wooden device left on museum grounds, which appears to have been used as a press with metal hardware and non-structural boards. The device was found in the Carriage House building, which is undergoing renovation that began in 2021 after being damaged in a storm in 2020. President of the museum's board of directors Elizabeth Ferguson posted a picture on social media seeking information on the device's source and original use.

title: APG Media of Chesapeake wins 19 press association awards
content: APG Media of Chesapeake won 19 press association awards in 16 categories at the Maryland-Delaware-DC Press Association's annual ceremony in Annapolis on May 3, 2024. The awards included a total of nine for The Star Democrat, with Maggie Trovato and Connie Connolly taking home first place wins, and Meredith Moore winning top prizes in two special section categories. title: Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 sentences:

TiShawna Jordan led a holiday concert at HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton, Maryland, to provide cheer and intervention for residents with memory loss. The event was part of a partnership between HeartFields and Chesapeake Center, which aims to support elderly individuals through volunteer-led events. According to Erin Lewis, director of career services at Chesapeake Center, TiShawna Jordan's concerts have provided holiday cheer and positive memory recollection to those in the Bridge to Rediscovery program. The first holiday concert was a success, with TiShawna being presented with roses by HeartFields Resident Ambassador.

title: All The Leaves Are Red, Yellow, and Orange - Top U.S. Destinations For Leaf Peeping And Other Fall Adventure
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 sentences:

California ranked top for fall foliage, with numerous national parks and scenic drives. New York topped the list for peak days of ideal leaf peeping, with over 31 days available. Washington State offered 12 weeks of peak viewing time due to its mountainous terrain, while Michigan had an extended season due to its inland location. Other popular destinations included Pennsylvania's Pocono Mountains, Vermont's sugarhouses and maple syrup tours, and Illinois' Morton Pumpkin Festival and corn mazes.

title: A 'smart buoy' is coming to St. Michaels harbor
content: The St. Michaels Climate Change/Sea Level Rise Commission will deploy a "smart buoy" in the harbor to monitor water levels and flooding, starting with permission from the commissioners. The buoy measures sea state, temperature, and wave action, as well as tidal head and pressure at its bottom. Andrew David Thaler presented the device, which is solar-powered and real-time data gathering, with one long-term goal being to establish a town-owned tide gauge in St. Michaels. The commission had previously applied for an equipment grant from So Far Ocean last year.

title: Women to Watch event recognizes 212 leaders
content: Shawna Payne was one of 14 women featured in this year's Women to Watch magazine, an annual publication by APG Chesapeake recognizing contributions of women to Mid-Shore workplaces and communities. The event, held April 9 at the Avalon Theatre, celebrated their accomplishments and honored potential for positive change. Orestes Baez, regional president of APG Chesapeake, attended with wife Betsy Griffin, general manager for sales and marketing. Yixin Qiu, co-founder of Apollo's Dream Foundation, and Jackie Wilson, senior vice president at Burke and Herbert Bank, were among three speakers who offered advice to the gathering. The fifth Women to Watch magazine was launched on April 9, with a preliminary printed version unveiled that evening.

title: Constitution Day includes Douglass reenactment
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

The Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance will host its second annual Constitution Day celebration on September 16, featuring a reenactment of Frederick Douglass by renowned actor Darius Wallace. The event will be held from noon-2 p.m. on the Talbot County Courthouse lawn, with additional activities including speakers, music, and an honor guard ceremony. This is part of a larger effort to promote civic engagement through education and constitutional values, led by the Mid-Shore Constitution Alliance in partnership with other organizations. The event is free and open to the public.

title: Colonel tops Easton, evens slate
content: Colonel Richardson defeated Easton High 58-24 on December 18, 2024. Colonels coach Bryan Hall attributed the win to "filling in" for lost starters. Elisee Pierre-Louis scored a takedown via injury default. The match saw Colonel's Ethan Thomas win by pinfall at 165 pounds, with Anthony Alexander and others contributing to the victory.

content: The article discusses a tournament bridge game where North led the diamond ace and West followed with three rounds of hearts to stop a diamond ruff in the dummy. The declarer won the hand with careful play, noting that if East had covered the club jack, declarer would have won.

title: Dubois readies for another fresh start
content: Pierre-Luc Dubois, chosen third in the 2016 draft, has been traded three times since 2021 to Winnipeg for Patrik Laine and Jack Roslovic, then to Los Angeles, and finally to the Washington Capitals. The trade was made by GM Rob Blake of the Kings, who acknowledged not putting Dubois in the right roles. Dubois turned 26 on Monday and aims to get back on track after a disappointing season with the Kings.

title: County offers training to prepare for disasters
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 4 concise sentences:

Talbot County Emergency Services offers free Community Emergency Response Training, held at the Talbot County Operations Center in Easton, starting September 18. The seven-session course includes emergency preparedness, fire safety, and hands-on activities taught by local first responders. Sessions run from 6 p.m. to 8:30 p.m., with participants required to attend all sessions; minors under 18 must be accompanied by an adult. To register, contact Geneva Schaffle at gschaffle@talbotcountymd.gov or call 410-770-8166.

content: Christmas events will be held in St. Michaels from Friday, Dec. 8 to Sunday, Dec. 10. The Union United Methodist Church will host a Christmas music concert on Sunday, Dec. 10 at 5 p.m.

title: Final Four beckons Bueckers and Clark
content: Caitlin Clark and Paige Bueckers will face off in the Final Four on Friday night as top-seeded Iowa and third-seeded UConn take center stage. title: Talbot Board of Ed voices mixed opinions over 2025-26 calendar draft
content:
Talbot County Board of Education members expressed mixed opinions over a draft calendar for the 2025-26 school year, which includes two days off in March and a five-day spring break from April 2 to April 6, 2026.
Helga Einhorn presented the draft calendar, but Board President Emily Jackson expressed confusion and concern about the lack of multiple drafts, stating she was expecting more diverse ideas. 
Board Members Deborah Bridges liked the March break, while Dyshekia Strawberry raised concerns about a shorter spring break potentially increasing chronic absenteeism in April.
Amy Dodson suggested moving an off day in March to extend spring break if needed, while Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized finding a balance between student needs and staff requirements.

title: Demir's hat trick paces Colonels
content: Morgan Demir scored a hat trick as Colonel Richardson High's boys soccer team beat Washington with a 5-0 shutout on September 19, 2024. Caleb Rouser and Jack Walls scored one goal each for the Colonels (4-0). Preston Rickwood and Aydan Downie had assists.

title: Former 1st-rounders Toney, Farley cut
content:
Kansas City receiver Kadarius Toney and Tennessee cornerback Caleb Farley, both first-round picks in the 2021 NFL draft, were cut from their teams as part of roster trimming before the regular season.

Toney was on his second team since being drafted by the New York Giants in 2021, while Farley started just twice due to injuries over his first two seasons with the Titans.

Teams had to cut their rosters to 53 players, and Toney, Farley, among hundreds of others, will be eligible for practice squads.

title: Talbot County farmers markets ready for spring season
content: Talbot County farmers markets will open in Easton on April 20 and St. Michaels on April 13. The Easton market will run on Saturdays from April to December, with vendors including Triangle Acres, Cottingham Farm, and Honeybee Flower Farm. The St. Michaels market will also run through November 23.

title: Snow fall brings snow day on the Eastern Shore
content: Residents of Easton woke up to two inches of snow on January 17, 2024, prompting a snow day for Talbot County Public Schools and closures for Dorchester County Public Schools due to icy road conditions. Easton's Superintendent of Public Works Mike Dickerson reported using 46.92 tons of salt on main roads. A winter weather advisory was issued for Queen Anne's, Talbot, and Caroline counties from early Tuesday morning until 1 p.m., with a chance of snow and freezing rain in the afternoon.

title: Body-worn camera footage from fatal officer-involved car crash released
content: Body-worn camera footage from a fatal officer-involved car crash on July 22 in Easton, Maryland was released by the Independent Investigations Division of the Maryland Office of the Attorney General. Deputies from Talbot County Sheriff's Office and Easton Police Department pursued a stolen vehicle driven by 18-year-old Yemaya Wilson at speeds over 100 MPH. The pursuit ended with the vehicle crashing on Route 50, resulting in fatal injuries to Wilson.

title: Pelosi, Biden: A fractured political friendship
content:
Here is a summary of the article in 2-5 concise sentences:

Nancy Pelosi was accused of playing a key role in convincing President Biden to withdraw from seeking re-election in late July. Pelosi made calls to Biden, expressing concerns about his re-election prospects, and also spoke with other Democratic Party power brokers. The outcome has energized the Democratic Party, increasing their chances of controlling Congress. However, Biden is reportedly angry with Pelosi, viewing her as "ruthless" and willing to prioritize party power over long-term relationships.

title: Jury finds Tilghman man guilty of child sexual abuse
content: A Talbot County jury found Eric L. Werner, 61, guilty of 16 counts related to the sexual abuse of a child, including sexual abuse of a minor, third-and fourth-degree sex offenses, and second-degree assault, in November 2023. Werner was acquitted on one count. The case began with an investigation by detectives from the Talbot County Sheriff's Office in February after learning of multiple child sexual abuse incidents at a home in Tilghman. Werner showed the child pornographic videos and engaged in inappropriate conversations before being arrested.

title: Talbot County passes 1-cent resolution for 2024 ballot
content: Talbot County Council passed a resolution on June 26, 2024, to place a question on the 2024 ballot to amend the county's charter to raise residents' taxes for public safety by up to 1 cent per $100 of assessed value above the revenue cap for seven years beginning July 1, 2026. The previous 1-cent resolution in 2020 was approved by voters and allowed for the addition of 26 public safety positions. The new resolution extends the funding for an additional two years.

title: Local author encourages 'choose love'
content: Abraham Keys, a local author from Rock Hall, MD, is releasing his third book "Kitty the Goat and the Puppy" with themes of love and acceptance, in what will be a five-part series about farm animals teaching lessons to children. The series was inspired by Keys' real-life farming experiences growing up in South America and Canada. His books have sold 3-4,000 copies since his first publication in December 2023, and he has been featured in four newspapers, including ones from Montana, Canada, and Maryland.

title: Was Biden's health cover-up worse than Watergate?
content: The book "Original Sin: President Biden's Decline, Its Cover-Up, and His Disastrous Choice to Run Again" coauthored by Jake Tapper and Alex Thompson has sparked a mixed reaction in the public regarding Biden's health cover-up and its comparison to Watergate. Congressional investigations are underway on Biden's mental decline during his presidency. The book suggests that Biden's cover-up may be worse than Watergate, with some media outlets criticized for not following up on similar scandals involving Democratic presidents like Bill Clinton.

title: Talbot County diversity training, statement stir dialogue
content: Talbot County Council Member Dave Stepp requests to repeal a diversity statement resolution passed in 2020. The statement defines diversity, equity and inclusion and outlines how employees can report discrimination. The proposed repeal was met with strong reactions from residents and organizations, including the Demarva Pride Center, which opposes the repeal. Former Talbot County President Corey Pack implemented the original resolutions and expressed disappointment that the council may be looking to remove the statement.
